Award.AwardTitle: RAPID: The Himalaya Connection Video, Outreach & Education

Directorate.LongName: Direct For Education and Human Resources

Award.AbstractNarration:
As part of its overall strategy to enhance learning in informal environments, the Advancing Informal STEM Learning (AISL) program funds innovative resources for use in a variety of settings. This project is a time sensitive educational response to the 7.8 magnitude earthquake that struck Nepal on April 25, 2015 and was followed by major aftershocks. This project builds on the intense worldwide interest in that disaster by developing and distributing media resources for the public and educators explaining the scientific research into tectonic and fluvial processes of this highly vulnerable region encompassing the Himalayas of Nepal, the Ganges-Brahmaputra River Delta of Bangladesh and India, and the mountains of northeastern India. Project deliverables include PBS NewsHour broadcasts and online stories, short videos for classroom use, 3D/2D videos for public screenings in museums, Earth Magazine blogs and articles, and DVDs.

Making new research understandable and accessible to the public is an important activity of the U.S. research enterprise. NSF is making a substantial investment in earth sciences research to increase knowledge of the conditions and processes that periodically cause earthquakes, landslides, and flooding. This education project leverages those investments and the public interest in the recent Nepal earthquake with a major public engagement opportunity that has the potential for reaching millions of students, teachers, and the public both in the U.S. and in other vulnerable regions.

POR.DRECONTENT:
This project was an NSF-funded effort to enhance the impact of a television documentary in production.  Entitled "The Himalaya Connection," the documentary tells the story of the extremely active geologic processes that built the Himalaya Mountains and surrounding lands.  It features new scientific research that enables scientists to better predict when and where future big earthquakes will strike the region and the preparations being made to make people safer in this densely-populated part of the world.  The deadly magnitude 7.8 Gorkha earthquake that struck Nepal in 2015 confirmed key scientific concepts and predictions about seismic activity in the Himalayas and provided many new scientific lessons, and there was an urgent need to relay this information to the hundreds of millions of people in the region still at risk from future large earthquakes so that they could better prepare for them.  The heightened interest in new information about this topic opened a unique window of opportunity to use a number of informal science education techniques to reach out to people.

This project produced several short videos for public screenings and viewing on the internet, incorporating new footage shot in Nepal and Bhutan; one video is entitled "The Next Himalayan Megaquake" and it explores seismic hazards and safety measures being taken in the Himalayan nations of Nepal, Bhutan, India, Pakistan, and China.  The other video, entitled "Giant Earthquakes in Bangladesh and India?," explores newly-discovered seismic hazards in Bangladesh and northeastern India and safety measures that could be taken to lessen the dangers there.  These videos are being screened in public presentations and at professional conferences alongside lectures by earthquake scientists.  To reach audiences in the at-risk countries in Asia, the videos were translated into Nepalese, Mizo, and Bengali.

To make the videos useful in classrooms, an educator produced a package of ancillary print materials which will be available on the PBS Learning Media web site for use by teachers.  For each video, the materials provide pre- and post-viewing activities and discussion questions/answers; vocabulary terms; activities that young people can do at home; and tips and information about earthquake safety.  Print copies of these materials (in English and local languages) are also being distributed to video screening organizers for handing out to attendees at screenings.

Another outreach avenue reaching thousands of people was a feature article in Earth magazine, a popular national geoscience publication.  The article told the behind-the-scenes story of the making of The Himalaya Connection documentary.  A series of blog entries, describing a film trip to the region, was also posted on Earth magazine's web site.

To further extend the usefulness of the video footage shot for the documentary, it was edited into a highlights reel that was provided to PBS Newshour for use in their news coverage of seismic hazards in the Himalayan region.

Broader impacts: These outreach and education products are widely accessible resources that explore the latest scientific insights into the potent geologic hazards of the region.  The videos, magazine articles, and blog have already reached a large audience, and the videos will continue doing so for several years, significantly raising awareness of the hazards and the importance of scientific research in areas that are highly susceptible to them.  Hundreds of millions of people remain at risk from the tectonically-induced hazards of earthquakes, landslides, and flooding; and scientists and safety experts in the at-risk region report to us that our materials are highly valued there because few sources of accurate, accessible information on this critical topic exist.  This impact may extend to users who access the materials in other places around the globe where similar geologic hazards exist, once the documentary is broadcast and the materials become more widely distributed.  Another impact has been to inspire young users, including those who live in the region at risk, to take a greater interest in pursuing careers in earth science, engineering, planning, and science communication; we and our colleagues have had numerous inquiries about pursuing these careers from young people exposed to our products.
